In South Africa, the key transmission vector of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is sexual transmission. In other countries, the main vector of transmission is drugs (Ukraine, Russia) or contaminated blood (China). The accelerated speed of the virus in South Africa may be because of the high incidence of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs). In turn, HIV causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). The immune system is severely weakened by HIV, making the body more susceptible to opportunistic infections that the body may normally be able to fight off but cannot because of a suppressed immune system. In this sense, the disease is then “acquired” because the body cannot resist it. The average time between HIV infection and progression to AIDS is approximately 10 years. This time period varies depending on factors such as access to AIDS drugs and, possibly, such factors as nutrition, stress levels, and the presence of other medical conditions.

HIV prevalence is given as a percentage of the population that is infected. For the purpose of producing a national or international HIV prevalence figure, researchers include all people with HIV infection who are alive at a given point in time, whether or not they have progressed to AIDS. According to estimates, 1,429 new infections occur daily. In 2006, 521,607 new infections took place. The estimated death rate for the same year was 354,378. In most cases, HIV prevalence cannot be accurately determined by reported cases because many infections are not diagnosed or reported. The best estimates are mainly based on the results of surveys of large groups of people (L. F. Johnson, Dorrington, & Matthews, 2007). The incidence of HIV refers to all new infections in a given period (Retrieved January 27, 2007, from http://www.avert.org/statistics.htm; http://www.avert.org/safricastats.hem and http://www.unaids.org/en/countryresponse/countries/south_africa.asp).

The spread of the disease in South Africa may be described as a generalized epidemic that reflects a high level of infection in the whole population of a particular country. On a global scale, the disease may be described as a pandemic. According to UNAIDS and WHO (2007, pp. 3-5), the global prevalence of HIV infection is remaining at the same level, but the global number of people living with HIV is increasing because of ongoing accumulation of new infections with longer survival times. In 2007, 22.5 million people in sub-Saharan Africa, the most affected region, were living with HIV, 1.7 million new infections occurred, and 1.6 million people died of AIDS. In the same year, the global figures were 33.2 million people living with HIV, 2.5 million new infections, and 2.1 million deaths.

According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (2004-2005), women in developing countries (e.g., South Africa) are more physically susceptible to HIV infection: Their partners are frequently engaged in risky sexual behavior, women are often forced to have sex, and they have little personal choice to remain abstinent or use contraceptives.

For example, the rate is 104.6 per 1,000 in comparison with 16.5 per 1,000 in the United Kingdom, 28.6 per 1,000 in the United States, and 4.8 per 1,000 in Ghana. The Crime Information Analysis Centre of the South African Police Service recorded 44,751 cases of rape and attempted rape in 1994-1995. The incidence of rape increased to 54,926 cases in 2005-2006 (SAIRR, 2007, p. 3). According to the South African Institute of Race Relations (SAIRR, 2007), the incidence of rape rose by 1.6% from 115.3 per 1,000 to 117.1 per 1,000 between 1994 and 2006.
The result was that the HIV-positive infection rate for pregnant women increased from 0.7% in 1990 to 29.5% in 2004 (Department of Health, 2004). Statistics quoted are from SAIRR (2004c).

A parliamentary committee report quoting a study by LoveLife, a NGO, found that 25% of young people believed that child rape cures HIV/AIDS. According to a survey by the Health Systems Trust, 9 of 10 people who tested HIV positive said that they were unable and fearful to tell their partners about their status (Business Day (SA), February 8, 2002; SAIRR, 2004c).
This includes placing South Africa on the U.S. Special 301 Watch List for countries that disregard intellectual property rights of U.S. firms.
The Department of Labour used the Doyle Model of Actuarial Projection developed by Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Statistics compiled by SAIRR (2005).

The electoral system (e.g., party list system) is dominated by party loyalties, not geographical constituencies, which means that there is no direct accountability by representatives to voters, many living with HIV/AIDS.
For the agenda preference of the South African government, see Beall, Gelb, and Hassim (2005); for the shortcomings of the government’s HIV/AIDS policy, see Whiteside and Poku (2004).
According to AVERT (2006), an international AIDS charity, in Uganda 51% of HIV-positive individuals are under treatment coverage, whereas only 21% are receiving drug treatment in South Africa.

Programs include National Aids Committee for South Africa, AIDS Program of the Government of National Unity, the musical Sarafini II, Beyond Awareness, Khomanani (“caring together”), and the National AIDS Council and Moral Regeneration Campaign. Adverse impacts of programs include downgrading of HIV/AIDS from a societal to a health problem; alienation of stakeholders and foreign donors; and failure of the Department of Education to reduce the high incidence rate of sexual abuse at schools, to reduce the high HIV infection rate of teachers, and to improve the insufficient human resources to provide life-skills education (Berry, 2004; De Souza, 2002; SAIRR, 2007). Statistics compiled by SAIRR (2006).
In 2003, the country had 274,635 health care professionals, but, according to the Department of Health, that left a shortage of 38,461 doctors and nurses in the public health sector (SAIRR, 2004c).

The study showed that the country will lose 16% of its health care workers to AIDS in the absence of antiretroviral (ARV) treatment. An estimated one million people sought care in the public health sector for HIV/AIDS-related illnesses, which burdened the already strained workload of the medical staff. Of the patients at medical and pediatric wards of public hospitals, 46% had HIV-related illnesses, and nearly all health facilities needed more staff to cope with the demands of HIV/AIDS. Of public hospitals, 32% were not even equipped with HIV test kits. Finally, the government’s policy communication was poor because less than 20% of health care managers had seen a copy of the Department of Health’s 2002–2005 National HIV/AIDS Plan. The shortage of health care professionals is part of South Africa’s general skills shortage. Statistics compiled by SAIRR (2007).

At the 16th International AIDS Conference in Canada, Dr. Tshabalal-Msimang, the South African Minister of Health, promoted alternative HIV/AIDS remedies, including garlic, beetroot, and lemons. As a result, a group of prominent HIV/AIDS scientists, among them the discoverer of HIV, Dr. Robert Gallo, petitioned President Thabo Mbeki to dismiss Dr. Tshabalal-Msimang. The petitions expressed concern over the proliferation of unproven remedies being marketed in South Africa, some with the support of the Minister of Health (SAIRR, 2007).

Two provinces, Guateng and Mpumalanga, with the highest HIV infection rates failed to spend all the money allocated to them in conditional grants to fight the epidemic in 2002-2003. Guateng spent only 50% of its allocated funds, whereas Mpumalanga spent only 38% (SAIRR, 2004c).

A report by the Institute of Security Studies and Transparency International concluded that it has become difficult to disentangle corruption from mismanagement and system failure as the root causes of the poor government response to the generalized epidemic (BBC News, 2007).

Another glaring example of the gap between verbal and physical action is the admission of former Vice President Jacob Zuma in court that he had unprotected sex with a known HIV-positive partner. During his tenure as Vice President, Zuma served as chairperson of the National AIDS Council and the Moral Regeneration Campaign (Van der Vliet, 2006, pp. 5-7).

See the Labour Relations Act (66 of 1995) and the Promotion of Equality and Prevention of Unfair Discrimination Act (4 of 2000), Constitution of the Republic of South Africa (108 of 1996), Basic Conditions for Employment Act (75 of 1997), Occupational Health and Safety Act (85 of 1993).

See Hoffman v. South African Airways (2000) and NS v. Old Mutual (2001), which was settled prior to trial by Old Mutual. Note: “NS” was the client of the Aids Law Project, unidentified for privacy reasons. In 2004, the number of registered health care professionals declined to 231,078, which included 31,214 physicians, of which only 9,527 were employed in the public sector (SAIRR, 2007).

Pregnant women are tested anonymously for HIV at public antenatal clinics. They leave the clinic ignorant of being HIV positive, will unknowingly infect their partners, and have a 50% chance of giving birth to HIV-positive babies.

The mining firm AngloGold estimated, in 2002, that HIV prevalence among its workers was 30%, costing between 1.1% and 5.8% of its payroll depending on the actuarial model utilized. By 2009, AngloGold estimated that the costs will rise to between 8% and 17% (World Economic Forum, 2003).
The exception is the financial sector, which employs more skilled workers but has experienced an increase in operations risk.
Prevalence rates are 18.4% in Kwazulu-Natal, 16.0% in Guateng, and 4.4% in the Western Cape (SAIRR, 2004b).

According to Health Insite, a consultancy firm, the present value of an HIV-positive employee to a company (including health care, productivity, replacement, and death and disability benefits) could be as high as 5 to 7 times the employee’s annual salary (Lundin, 2002).

The South African Business Coalition on HIV and AIDS (SABCOHA) survey sample revealed the skills distribution of the labor force in financial services is 39% highly skilled, 43% skilled, and 18% semi- or unskilled.

The impact of HIV/AIDS on suppliers has not been investigated. Under Black Economic Empowerment, the government’s broad-based affirmative action program for industry, companies will be expected to buy more from Black-owned suppliers. This may mean that companies will come under pressure to extend HIV/AIDS-intervention programs to suppliers in the future.
The SRI is inline with the Second King Code on Corporate Governance, a government commission of inquiry.

The World Bank (2000) estimated that South Africa’s GDP will be 17% lower by 2010 because of the HIV/AIDS epidemic. In general, the epidemic has a negative bearing on economic growth (Bloom & Mahal, 1997).
Statistics quoted are in SAIRR (2004c, pp. 294-295).
The latest available unemployment rate (expanded definition) is 41% (SAIRR, 2005). The proportion of Africans living in poverty in South Africa has risen from 50% in 1996 to 61% in 2004.

Manufacturers in India, Brazil, and Thailand have created generic versions of various name-brand ARV drugs. Indian manufacturers Cipla, Ltd. and Hetero Drugs, Ltd. offer HIV/AIDS drugs for approximately 40% below the prices offered by GlaxoSmithKline and others.

South African definitions are as follows: large company > 500 employees, a medium company = 100 to 500 employees, a small company = 50 to 100 employees, and a micro company < 50 employees. Anglo American, the mining multinational enterprise, estimates that the treatment regime it provides for infected workers may cost as much as R25,000 per year for each worker. For detailed outlines of the HIV/AIDS programs financed by large firms, see http://www.businessfightsaids.org, http://www.bp.com, and http://www.hivan.org.za.

Save the Children, an initiative by international NGOs, provides Childhood Challenges—A Toolkit for Action for HIV/AIDS Affecting Children (available from http://www.hivan.org.za). South Africa has 1 million AIDS orphans plus another 9 million children living in infected or sick families.

Foreign direct investment (FDI) is lower in South African industries with high infection rates. In the manufacturing sector, FDI has declined from 41.3% of total FDI (1994) to 26.3% (2002). Here, the workforce is predominantly semi- and unskilled, which are also the skills groups with the highest infection rates. In the financial sector, which relies on skilled and highly skilled labor with a lower HIV/AIDS infection rate, FDI (% of total FDI) has remained relatively stable: 30.8% (1994) and 31.9% (2002). However, in the mining sector, which primarily uses semi- and unskilled workers and where infection rates are the highest, FDI (% of total FDI) increased from 5.4% (1994) to 31.5% (2002). FDI driven by resource endowment factors in the resource extractive industry tends to accept higher-risk exposure (South African Reserve Bank, 2004, pp. 102-103).

Some firms employ the practice of “shadowing,” in which two or even three workers are trained to perform the same duty in an effort to maintain productivity in the face of absenteeism or mortality because of HIV/AIDS-related illnesses.
For statistical detail for risk assessment, see SABCOHA (2005; especially Figures 20, 21, and 22).

Gold Fields’s Informed, Consented, Voluntary Counseling and Testing Program encompasses the following elements: Every person in the company has been exposed to at least one HIV/AIDS awareness program; awareness programs include celebrity speakers, industrial theater, and peer educators; 250,000 free condoms per month are distributed to employees, the general community, and sex workers; negotiating skills are taught to sex workers to promote safe sex; and research in vaccines, the role of immune boosters, and ARV therapy is supported (Retrieved on October 31, 2008, from Gold Fields, http://www.onlinewebstudio.co.za/websites/goldfields/sus_health_safety.php).
According to Connelly and Rosen (2004), most SMEs have not offered prevention and treatment services.

Paul Kapelus of the African Institute of Corporate Citizenship, a NGO, wants to move corporations toward a way of doing business that incorporates the triple bottom line—that is, acknowledging and improving the economic, environmental, and social impact of their activities (Ludman, 2003).

This will be a practical approach because the government provides only approximately 40% of health services, whereas the private sector provides the rest. Also, successful lobbying by the business community led to new legislation in 2006 that medical treatment provided by firms will be tax deductible. The legislation was welcomed by businesses that wanted to provide ARV treatment to their HIV-positive employees (Naido, 2006).

Fears for unfair dismissal of HIV-positive workers are unfounded; infected workers are protected under South African law. Political scientists often view HIV/AIDS in a societal rather than individual manner. Elbe (2006) cautioned that the pandemic may be viewed as a security issue as well as one of public health, development, economics, politics, and gender.
